summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting an interview with Jeffrey Epstein on May 8, 2002. Epstein describes being approached by Laurence S. Zimmerman for a $15 million bridge loan to finance the acquisition of Winstar Communications, and how he discovered the collateral documents were forged, leading him to back out of the deal and report it to authorities.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI interview. He describes being solicited for a $15 million bridge loan by Laurence Zimmerman for the acquisition of Winstar Communications, and how he discovered the collateral documents were forged.

persons.name: Laurence S. Zimmerman
persons.context: Approached Epstein for a $15 million bridge loan to finance Winstar Communications acquisition through his company Wintel. Provided forged collateral documents, leading Epstein to cancel the deal.

persons.name: Jeffrey Schantz
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who was present during the FBI interview. Epstein instructed Zimmerman to direct all future loan dealings to Schantz.

persons.name: James P. Whittier
persons.context: Sent a fax with a term sheet for the bridge loan to Epstein from Landtel. Epstein states he never spoke with him.

persons.name: Jay Phillip Parker
persons.context: Name appeared on faxes from Landtel received by Epstein. Epstein states he never spoke with him.

persons.name: Kevin Keo
persons.context: Former Wells Fargo employee contacted by Epstein who confirmed his signature was forged on safekeeping receipts and that Williams Management and Capital Group was under investigation.

persons.name: Mark Williams
persons.context: Epstein states he never spoke with Mark Williams or anyone at Williams Management and Capital Group (WMACGL).

persons.name: John Macari

connections.description: Zimmerman solicited Epstein for a $15 million bridge loan. They were introduced socially and occasionally met at events.
Schantz is Epstein's attorney and was present during the FBI interview. Epstein directed Zimmerman to deal with Schantz on the loan.
Whittier sent faxes related to the bridge loan deal on Landtel stationery. Described as an associate of Zimmerman.
Parker's name appeared on faxes related to the bridge loan deal. Described as an associate of Zimmerman.
Forged collateral documents for the loan were on stationery from Williams' company, Williams Management and Capital Group Ltd. (WMACGL).

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was interviewed by the FBI in 2002 regarding a potential $15 million bridge loan to Laurence Zimmerman, which Epstein backed out of after discovering forged collateral documents.
Epstein discovered that safekeeping receipts for U.S. Treasury Bonds, purportedly verified by a Wells Fargo banker named 'Kevin Keon', were forgeries after contacting the real banker, Kevin Keo.
The proposed loan was to finance Zimmerman's company Wintel Telecom Holdings Inc.'s acquisition of the bankrupt Winstar Communications Inc.
Epstein reported the attempted fraud to the Bankruptcy Court in Delaware after terminating the deal.

The document shows Epstein acting as a potential victim of financial fraud, a contrast to his later notoriety, and reveals his ownership of homes in Aspen, Palm Beach, and the Virgin Islands at that time.
